message.content:
cs.SI, cs.SOC, cs.IR, cs.LG, cs.CYBER. 

The paper deals with social media and controversial issues, which suggests that it could belong to the cs.SOC (Social and Information Networks) sub-category. The use of an endorsement graph and an edge-recommendation problem suggests that it could also belong to the cs.SI (Social and Information Retrieval) sub-category. The paper also mentions the use of a controversy score, which could place it in the cs.IR (Information Retrieval) sub-category. The proposed algorithm and its efficiency could suggest that it belongs to the cs.LG (Machine Learning) sub-category. Finally, the topic of reducing controversy on social media could also place it in the cs.CYBER (Cybersecurity) sub-category.
